cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who said one man's vulgarity is another's lyric
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: The phrase "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric" reflects the idea that what one person finds offensive or vulgar, another may find beautiful or artistic. This quote is often associated with discussions about art, music, and cultural expression. The quote is attributed to the American poet and writer, Allen Ginsberg, who was known for his provocative and boundary-pushing works during the Beat Generation.

Answer: Allen Ginsberg.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who said one man's vulgarity is another's lyric
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Court voted 5–4 in favor of Cohen. Justice Harlan wrote "[A]bsent a more particularized and compelling reason for its actions, the State may not, consistently with the First and Fourteenth Amendments, make the simple public display of this single four-letter expletive a criminal offense." In the court\'s opinion, Harlan also penned the now famous line "one man\'s vulgarity is another\'s lyric".\n', 'BULLET::::- "What One Man Said to Another: Talks with Richard Selzer" (1994; with Peter Josyph)\n', 'In 2017, poet Joel Sadler-Puckering included a poem about Vincent in his collection, ‘I Know Why the Gay Man Dances’. The poem uses details about Vincent that were shared in the ‘Dreams of a Life’ documentary.\n', 'Vy comes to swinging 1940s Harlem to write songs for the Duke, Harlem\'s greatest band leader. To overcome the sexist barriers of the time against women songwriters, she disguises herself as a man, Vy-man. She finds the Duke in tears over his loss of Lady Liv, Harlem\'s "queen of the blues". The Duke likes Vy-man\'s music, so he instructs the songwriter to go to the Cotton Club and present one of her songs as if it were a new song written by the Duke for Lady Liv. Lady Liv finds Vy-man charming, and a series of mistaken pairings results.\n', 'Lewis has released many music spoofs. Artists he has parodied include Tinchy Stryder, N-Dubz, Jay-Z and Alicia Keys. On 14 July 2009 he and his close friend Daniel Kaluuya released a parody of Boy Better Know\'s "Too Many Man", titled "Too Many Weave". It was based upon the fact they thought that nowadays too many women wear fake hair (hair extensions). The video was in YouTube\'s Most Viewed for 14, 15 and 16 July that year.\n', '"One Man Guy" is a song written by American singer-songwriter Loudon Wainwright III. It originally appeared on his 1985 studio album "I\'m Alright", and was included on his 2009 compilation album "Essential Recordings: One Man Guy".\n', 'Rabbi Simeon ben Yohai compared the words of "Shall one man sin, and will You be wrathful with all the congregation?" to the case of men on a ship, one of whom took a borer and began boring beneath his own place. His shipmates asked him what he was doing. He replied that what he was doing would not matter to them, as he was boring under his own place. And they replied that the water would come up and flood the ship for them all.\n', 'Similarly, during this era, there were periodic "purity campaigns" on radio, as individual stations decided to ban songs with double-entendres or alleged vulgar lyrics. One victim of such a campaign was bandleader Joe Rines, who in November 1931, was cut off in mid-song by John L. Clark, program director of WBZ, for performing a number called "This is the Missus", whose lyrics Clark deemed inappropriate. Rines was indignant, saying he believed Clark was over-reacting to a totally innocent song, but Clark insisted he was right to ban any song whose lyrics might be construed as suggestive.\n', "'Vulgar scandal' is an idiom Shakespeare has in common with Fulke Greville. 'Vulgar' is used in Shakespeare to refer to the base, the common, the popular: the speech by Henry IV to Hal deplores Hal making himself 'stale and cheap to vulgar company', in a speech that turns on the proper decorum of how a person should relate to the multitude.\n", 'Even so, Poe has received not only praise, but criticism as well. This is partly because of the negative perception of his personal character and its influence upon his reputation. William Butler Yeats was occasionally critical of Poe and once called him "vulgar". Transcendentalist Ralph Waldo Emerson reacted to "The Raven" by saying, "I see nothing in it", and derisively referred to Poe as "the jingle man". Aldous Huxley wrote that Poe\'s writing "falls into vulgarity" by being "too poetical"—the equivalent of wearing a diamond ring on every finger.\n']

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:
The phrase "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric" is a powerful statement that underscores the subjective nature of language and artistic expression. It suggests that what one individual may perceive as offensive or vulgar, another may interpret as beautiful or meaningful. This quote is often invoked in discussions surrounding art, music, and cultural expression, where the boundaries of acceptability are frequently tested.

Importantly, this quote is attributed to Justice Potter Stewart Harlan in the context of a Supreme Court decision regarding free speech. In this case, the Court was addressing the issue of whether the state could criminalize the public display of a vulgar expression. Justice Harlan emphasized that without a compelling reason, the state could not restrict free speech based solely on the perceived vulgarity of a word or phrase. This legal context is crucial as it situates the quote within the framework of the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution, which protect individual rights to free expression.

The implications of this quote extend beyond legal discourse into cultural and philosophical realms. It invites reflection on how societal norms shape our understanding of language and art. The quote serves as a reminder that cultural standards are not static; they evolve over time, influenced by changing values and perspectives. This relativity of interpretation encourages ongoing dialogue about what constitutes vulgarity versus artistry.

In summary, the quote "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric" encapsulates a complex interplay of legal, cultural, and philosophical themes. It highlights the importance of context in interpreting language and expression, emphasizing that perceptions of vulgarity and artistry are deeply subjective and influenced by individual experiences and societal norms.

### Answer:
The phrase "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric" was articulated by Justice Potter Stewart Harlan in a Supreme Court decision regarding free speech.

The phrase "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric" is attributed to Justice Potter Stewart Harlan in the context of a Supreme Court decision regarding free speech. This line encapsulates the subjective nature of language and expression, suggesting that what one person may find offensive or vulgar, another may appreciate as artistic or lyrical. This idea is particularly relevant in discussions about censorship, artistic expression, and the First Amendment rights in the United States.

### Foundational Knowledge:
1. **Context of the Phrase**: The phrase originates from a Supreme Court case where the Court ruled in favor of Cohen, who was charged for wearing a jacket with an expletive. Justice Harlan's opinion emphasized the importance of protecting free expression, even if it includes language that some may find objectionable.

2. **Subjectivity of Language**: The phrase illustrates the concept that language and its interpretations can vary widely among individuals and cultures. What is deemed vulgar in one context may be celebrated in another, reflecting personal, cultural, and societal differences.

3. **First Amendment Implications**: The phrase is significant in discussions about the First Amendment, which protects freedom of speech. It highlights the ongoing debate about the limits of free expression and the role of government in regulating speech.

### Advanced Information:
1. **Censorship and Artistic Expression**: The phrase can be used to analyze various instances of censorship in art, music, and literature, where authorities or societal norms attempt to regulate what is considered acceptable. This raises questions about who gets to define vulgarity and the implications for artists and creators.

2. **Cultural Relativism**: The idea behind the phrase can be linked to broader themes in cultural studies, where the interpretation of art and language is seen as relative to the cultural context. This can lead to discussions about how different societies value different forms of expression.

3. **Historical Perspectives**: The phrase also invites a historical examination of how perceptions of vulgarity and artistry have evolved over time. For instance, what was once considered vulgar in literature or music may later be recognized as groundbreaking or influential.

### Role of These Contents:
Understanding the phrase "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric" requires an appreciation of its legal, cultural, and artistic implications. It serves as a lens through which to examine the complexities of language, the nature of artistic expression, and the ongoing tensions between freedom of speech and societal norms. By exploring these dimensions, one can gain a deeper insight into the dynamics of communication and the importance of protecting diverse forms of expression in a pluralistic society.

### Summary:
The phrase attributed to Justice Harlan encapsulates the subjective nature of language and expression, highlighting the complexities of free speech and censorship. It invites exploration into the cultural, historical, and legal contexts of vulgarity and artistry, emphasizing the importance of protecting diverse expressions in society. Understanding this phrase enriches discussions about the role of language in shaping human experience and the ongoing debates surrounding artistic freedom.

The phrase "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric" is often misattributed to various figures, including poets and writers like Allen Ginsberg. However, it is actually attributed to Justice Potter Stewart Harlan in the context of a Supreme Court ruling regarding free speech. This phrase encapsulates the subjective nature of language and expression, emphasizing that what one individual may find offensive or vulgar, another may appreciate as artistic or lyrical.

1. **Context of the Phrase**: The phrase emerged from a Supreme Court case involving Cohen, who was charged for wearing a jacket with an expletive. Justice Harlan's opinion highlighted the necessity of protecting free expression, even when it includes language that some may find objectionable. This legal context underscores the importance of the First Amendment in safeguarding diverse forms of expression.

2. **Subjectivity of Language**: The phrase illustrates the variability in how language is interpreted across different individuals and cultures. This subjectivity is crucial in discussions about art, music, and literature, where the boundaries of what is considered acceptable or vulgar can shift dramatically based on cultural norms and personal perspectives.

3. **First Amendment Implications**: The phrase is significant in the discourse surrounding the First Amendment, which protects freedom of speech. It raises important questions about the limits of free expression and the role of government in regulating speech, particularly in artistic contexts.

4. **Censorship and Artistic Expression**: The phrase can be applied to analyze instances of censorship in various artistic domains, where societal norms or authorities attempt to regulate what is deemed acceptable. This leads to discussions about the power dynamics involved in defining vulgarity and the implications for artists and creators.

5. **Cultural Relativism**: The phrase connects to broader themes in cultural studies, emphasizing that interpretations of art and language are relative to cultural contexts. This perspective encourages a deeper understanding of how different societies value and respond to various forms of expression.

6. **Historical Perspectives**: The phrase invites an examination of how perceptions of vulgarity and artistry have evolved over time. What was once considered vulgar may later be recognized as groundbreaking, reflecting changing societal values and norms.

By integrating these insights, we can appreciate the complexities surrounding the phrase and its implications for discussions about language, art, and freedom of expression. The phrase serves as a lens through which to explore the ongoing tensions between individual expression and societal standards, highlighting the need for a nuanced understanding of artistic freedom.

### Answer:
The phrase "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric" is attributed to Justice Potter Stewart Harlan in the context of a Supreme Court decision regarding free speech.

To answer the following question:
who said one man's vulgarity is another's lyric

['The Court voted 5–4 in favor of Cohen. Justice Harlan wrote "[A]bsent a more particularized and compelling reason for its actions, the State may not, consistently with the First and Fourteenth Amendments, make the simple public display of this single four-letter expletive a criminal offense." In the court\'s opinion, Harlan also penned the now famous line "one man\'s vulgarity is another\'s lyric".\n', 'BULLET::::- "What One Man Said to Another: Talks with Richard Selzer" (1994; with Peter Josyph)\n', 'In 2017, poet Joel Sadler-Puckering included a poem about Vincent in his collection, ‘I Know Why the Gay Man Dances’. The poem uses details about Vincent that were shared in the ‘Dreams of a Life’ documentary.\n', 'Vy comes to swinging 1940s Harlem to write songs for the Duke, Harlem\'s greatest band leader. To overcome the sexist barriers of the time against women songwriters, she disguises herself as a man, Vy-man. She finds the Duke in tears over his loss of Lady Liv, Harlem\'s "queen of the blues". The Duke likes Vy-man\'s music, so he instructs the songwriter to go to the Cotton Club and present one of her songs as if it were a new song written by the Duke for Lady Liv. Lady Liv finds Vy-man charming, and a series of mistaken pairings results.\n', 'Lewis has released many music spoofs. Artists he has parodied include Tinchy Stryder, N-Dubz, Jay-Z and Alicia Keys. On 14 July 2009 he and his close friend Daniel Kaluuya released a parody of Boy Better Know\'s "Too Many Man", titled "Too Many Weave". It was based upon the fact they thought that nowadays too many women wear fake hair (hair extensions). The video was in YouTube\'s Most Viewed for 14, 15 and 16 July that year.\n', '"One Man Guy" is a song written by American singer-songwriter Loudon Wainwright III. It originally appeared on his 1985 studio album "I\'m Alright", and was included on his 2009 compilation album "Essential Recordings: One Man Guy".\n', 'Rabbi Simeon ben Yohai compared the words of "Shall one man sin, and will You be wrathful with all the congregation?" to the case of men on a ship, one of whom took a borer and began boring beneath his own place. His shipmates asked him what he was doing. He replied that what he was doing would not matter to them, as he was boring under his own place. And they replied that the water would come up and flood the ship for them all.\n', 'Similarly, during this era, there were periodic "purity campaigns" on radio, as individual stations decided to ban songs with double-entendres or alleged vulgar lyrics. One victim of such a campaign was bandleader Joe Rines, who in November 1931, was cut off in mid-song by John L. Clark, program director of WBZ, for performing a number called "This is the Missus", whose lyrics Clark deemed inappropriate. Rines was indignant, saying he believed Clark was over-reacting to a totally innocent song, but Clark insisted he was right to ban any song whose lyrics might be construed as suggestive.\n', "'Vulgar scandal' is an idiom Shakespeare has in common with Fulke Greville. 'Vulgar' is used in Shakespeare to refer to the base, the common, the popular: the speech by Henry IV to Hal deplores Hal making himself 'stale and cheap to vulgar company', in a speech that turns on the proper decorum of how a person should relate to the multitude.\n", 'Even so, Poe has received not only praise, but criticism as well. This is partly because of the negative perception of his personal character and its influence upon his reputation. William Butler Yeats was occasionally critical of Poe and once called him "vulgar". Transcendentalist Ralph Waldo Emerson reacted to "The Raven" by saying, "I see nothing in it", and derisively referred to Poe as "the jingle man". Aldous Huxley wrote that Poe\'s writing "falls into vulgarity" by being "too poetical"—the equivalent of wearing a diamond ring on every finger.\n']

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

The phrase "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric" encapsulates the idea that perceptions of vulgarity and artistry are subjective; what one individual finds offensive, another may appreciate as beautiful or meaningful. This quote is often discussed in the context of art, music, and cultural expression. 

However, contrary to the attribution to Allen Ginsberg, the correct attribution of this quote is to Justice Harlan in a Supreme Court opinion related to the case involving the First Amendment. In this context, Justice Harlan articulated that the state cannot criminalize the public display of certain expressions without compelling justification, highlighting the subjective nature of language and expression.

The relevant passage states: "The Court voted 5–4 in favor of Cohen. Justice Harlan wrote '[A]bsent a more particularized and compelling reason for its actions, the State may not, consistently with the First and Fourteenth Amendments, make the simple public display of this single four-letter expletive a criminal offense.' In the court's opinion, Harlan also penned the now famous line 'one man's vulgarity is another's lyric.'"

To enhance the reasoning process, it is essential to clarify that:

1. The quote is specifically attributed to Justice Harlan, not Allen Ginsberg, which is a crucial correction to prevent misinformation.
2. The context of the quote is rooted in a legal framework concerning freedom of speech, emphasizing its significance in discussions about the boundaries of expression in society.

By incorporating this accurate attribution and context, the model can avoid potential inaccuracies and better understand the implications of the quote.

**Answer:**
The quote "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric" is attributed to Justice Harlan in a Supreme Court opinion regarding the First Amendment, not to Allen Ginsberg.

question_info.question: who said one man's vulgarity is another's lyric
passages:
The Court voted 5–4 in favor of Cohen. Justice Harlan wrote "[A]bsent a more particularized and compelling reason for its actions, the State may not, consistently with the First and Fourteenth Amendments, make the simple public display of this single four-letter expletive a criminal offense." In the court's opinion, Harlan also penned the now famous line "one man's vulgarity is another's lyric".
BULLET::::- "What One Man Said to Another: Talks with Richard Selzer" (1994; with Peter Josyph)
In 2017, poet Joel Sadler-Puckering included a poem about Vincent in his collection, ‘I Know Why the Gay Man Dances’. The poem uses details about Vincent that were shared in the ‘Dreams of a Life’ documentary.
Vy comes to swinging 1940s Harlem to write songs for the Duke, Harlem's greatest band leader. To overcome the sexist barriers of the time against women songwriters, she disguises herself as a man, Vy-man. She finds the Duke in tears over his loss of Lady Liv, Harlem's "queen of the blues". The Duke likes Vy-man's music, so he instructs the songwriter to go to the Cotton Club and present one of her songs as if it were a new song written by the Duke for Lady Liv. Lady Liv finds Vy-man charming, and a series of mistaken pairings results.
Lewis has released many music spoofs. Artists he has parodied include Tinchy Stryder, N-Dubz, Jay-Z and Alicia Keys. On 14 July 2009 he and his close friend Daniel Kaluuya released a parody of Boy Better Know's "Too Many Man", titled "Too Many Weave". It was based upon the fact they thought that nowadays too many women wear fake hair (hair extensions). The video was in YouTube's Most Viewed for 14, 15 and 16 July that year.
"One Man Guy" is a song written by American singer-songwriter Loudon Wainwright III. It originally appeared on his 1985 studio album "I'm Alright", and was included on his 2009 compilation album "Essential Recordings: One Man Guy".
Rabbi Simeon ben Yohai compared the words of "Shall one man sin, and will You be wrathful with all the congregation?" to the case of men on a ship, one of whom took a borer and began boring beneath his own place. His shipmates asked him what he was doing. He replied that what he was doing would not matter to them, as he was boring under his own place. And they replied that the water would come up and flood the ship for them all.
Similarly, during this era, there were periodic "purity campaigns" on radio, as individual stations decided to ban songs with double-entendres or alleged vulgar lyrics. One victim of such a campaign was bandleader Joe Rines, who in November 1931, was cut off in mid-song by John L. Clark, program director of WBZ, for performing a number called "This is the Missus", whose lyrics Clark deemed inappropriate. Rines was indignant, saying he believed Clark was over-reacting to a totally innocent song, but Clark insisted he was right to ban any song whose lyrics might be construed as suggestive.
'Vulgar scandal' is an idiom Shakespeare has in common with Fulke Greville. 'Vulgar' is used in Shakespeare to refer to the base, the common, the popular: the speech by Henry IV to Hal deplores Hal making himself 'stale and cheap to vulgar company', in a speech that turns on the proper decorum of how a person should relate to the multitude.
Even so, Poe has received not only praise, but criticism as well. This is partly because of the negative perception of his personal character and its influence upon his reputation. William Butler Yeats was occasionally critical of Poe and once called him "vulgar". Transcendentalist Ralph Waldo Emerson reacted to "The Raven" by saying, "I see nothing in it", and derisively referred to Poe as "the jingle man". Aldous Huxley wrote that Poe's writing "falls into vulgarity" by being "too poetical"—the equivalent of wearing a diamond ring on every finger.
